#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Idle a Car
#Text=If you ’re working on your car , you may need to idle the car to warm up its engine .
#Text=Idling is also great for warming up your car in winter .
#Text=To idle your vehicle , all you need to do is let it run while stationary .
#Text=But before you do , check the EPA ’s website to find out if your local laws allow you to leave your car idling .
#Text=In some states , idling for long periods is illegal and could result in a fine .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Idling with an Automatic Transmission
#Text=Turn on the car .
#Text=On the right side of the steering column of most cars , you ’ll find the ignition slot for the key .
#Text=Insert your key into the ignition and turn it halfway to turn on the car ’s power .
#Text=After that , continue to twist the key until you hear the engine start , then release the key .
#Text=Avoid holding the key in the engine starting position once the car is started .
#Text=Continuing to hold the ignition in the starting position after the car is started can damage the engine .
#Text=Some car models may have a different engine ignition sequence .
#Text=New cars often have a push-button starter , where you only have to hold down the brake pedal and press a button to start the car .
#Text=Bring the car to a stop or keep it in park .
#Text=If your car is in motion , apply gently increasing pressure to the brake pedal to slow the car until it comes to a stop .
#Text=If the car is in park , you wo n’t need to do anything special .
#Text=As the car runs while stationary , the engine will idle .
#Text=If your car was in motion , after it has been brought to a stop you can put it in park so you do n’t have to keep holding down the brake pedal .
#Text=In high traffic situations , do not put the car in park after coming to a stop .
#Text=Instead , keep the brake pedal pressed down fully and your car will idle .
#Text=Allow the engine to continue running .
#Text=If you ’re starting your car cold , it ’ll need some time for the engine to reach its normal idling temperature .
#Text=Warmup times will depend on your car model , but if you watch the RPM gauge , after the car cycles through a period of high RPMs , it should be warmed up .
#Text=Idling with a Manual Transmission
#Text=Check the parking brake before starting the car .
#Text=Manual transmission cars are usually parked in neutral with the parking brake engaged .
#Text=Depending on your model of car , the position of the parking brake may vary , though you can often find it on the center console .
#Text=Press down the clutch while applying light pressure to the brake .
#Text=There are three pedals below the steering column in manual transmission cars .
#Text=From right to left , these pedals operate the accelerator , the brake , and the clutch .
#Text=Make sure the clutch is pressed all the way down with your foot as you use your other foot to apply gentle pressure to the brake .
#Text=Twist the key in the ignition to start the car .
#Text=Locate the ignition on the right side of the steering column and insert your key .
#Text=While continuing to hold down the clutch and brake with your feet , turn the key halfway to supply power to the car .
#Text=Continue to twist the key until you hear the car start , then release the key .
#Text=Make sure you release the key as soon as you hear the engine engage .
#Text=Holding the key in the engine start position once the engine is running is harmful to the engine .
#Text=Once the engine is started , check that the shifter is in neutral , which is usually located on the center console .
#Text=If in neutral , the shifter should be able to move left to right .
#Text=After you 've verified the car is in neutral , you can release the clutch .
#Text=If the parking brake is engaged , you can release the brake , too .
#Text=Downshift
#Text=to neutral or keep the stationary car in neutral .
#Text=If you ’re in motion , you ’ll need to press down the clutch and move the gear shifter into the neutral position with your hand .
#Text=If your car is already stationary in neutral , when the engine starts the car will idle .
#Text=When the car comes to a stop , you 'll need to hold down the brake engage the parking brake to prevent the car from rolling .
#Text=Keep the engine running while the car is stopped .
#Text=It may take a few minutes before your engine heats up to normal operating temperature .
#Text=You ’ll know the engine is warm when you see the RPMs spike .
#Text=After that , your engine should be idling warm .
#Text=Preventing Excessive Idling
#Text=Turn the car off if you 'll be idling more than 10 seconds .
#Text=Though you may have heard otherwise , idling can burn more fuel than restarting your car .
#Text=If you think you ’ll be stopped for longer than 10 seconds , turn off your engine to save fuel .
#Text=Never stop your engine in high traffic conditions , at stoplights , or in stop-and-go traffic .
#Text=Doing so can dangerously reduce your reaction time .
#Text=Drive your car to warm up its cabin in cold weather .
#Text=Driving your car for a short while will warm it up twice as fast in cold weather as it would idling .
#Text=Additionally , a short drive generally uses less fuel than it would take to warm up the engine with idling .
#Text=When driving , avoid revving up your engine unnecessarily .
#Text=This will cause needless fuel waste .
#Text=An easy drive will warm up your car with minimal fuel usage .
#Text=Refrain from using the drive-through window at stores .
#Text=Drive-through windows at establishments generally require you to wait with your car idling while the items you ordered are prepared .
#Text=Instead , park your car and make your order inside the establishment to save fuel .
#Text=In the event you need to use a drive-through window , you can minimize fuel consumption by turning your car off while waiting for your order .
#Text=Tips
#Text=When you hop into your car , make sure you buckle up your seatbelt .
#Text=Seatbelts greatly reduce the risk of serious injury or harm in the event of an accident , and in many places , buckling up is the law .
